citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There is an expired bottle of Carbocaine-V located in the safe that expired on 8/2025. It is stored in the safe with other
drugs currently being used. The use of expired medication is not considered to be a safe or appropriate method to
prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries since the expected results cannot be guaranteed. The facility
must ensure the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee
must ensure all medications on-hand are not expired. Corrected at time of inspection on December 2, 2025, by throwing
medication away.

The housing facilities of the wolf-hybrids still contain several metal guillotine gates that are entirely rusted. These gates
allow the staff to move the wolf-hybrids into a secure pen or shift to a different enclosure. Rust can cause weakness in the
structural strength of the metal gates. Also, rust cannot be properly cleaned and sanitized. Surfaces that cannot be
cleaned and sanitized could cause infection if bacteria or viruses are harbored in the material. Any surfaces that come in
contact with the wolf-hybrids must be free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitization, or that
affects the structural strength of the surface. To be corrected by March 2, 2026.

On September 3rd, 2025, the female wolf-hybrid “Ashima” was reported to have diarrhea, vomiting, bloating, and lethargy.
The medical records do not have the problem identified, date and description of the problem, exam findings, or plan for
treatment and care. The records only contain a fecal exam showing a positive result for tapeworms and treatment with
Credelio Quattro. Correct and updated medical records allow the AV to monitor and effectively treat medical problems in
wolf-hybrids and allows all caretakers to follow plans for treatments and care. The registrant must ensure that when a
problem is identified (such as a disease, injury, or illness), the date and description of the problem, examination findings,
test results, plan for treatment and care, and treatment procedures performed are documented in the medical record and
available at time of inspection. To be corrected by December 15, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
